sub_title: Researcher | Lecturer | Power Systems | PhD in Electrical Engineering
summary:
As a Researcher/Lecturer at Eindhoven University of Technology (TU/e) in the Electrical Engineering Department, I have been working on Flexible AC/DC-link applied in MV-Grids (FLINK) project since 2019. This project is funded by the Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend Nederland (RvO) and coordinated by DNV GL, aiming to enhance the hosting capacity and power quality of the grid. I have contributed to the development and implementation of innovative optimization methods and algorithms for the FLINK project, as well as published multiple papers and book chapters on this topic.

I have over 6 years of experience in Power Systems Analysis and Optimization, Power Quality, Hosting Capacity analysis, Distribution Systems, Transmission Systems, and Industrial Systems. I hold a PhD in Electrical Engineering from Universidade Federal de Itajubá (UNIFEI), where I developed expertise in these fields. I also teach courses such as Power Systems Analysis, Systems Integration, and Power Quality at TU/e, and I am a certified student coach at the Honors Academy (Energy transition track). I am passionate about advancing the knowledge and practice of power systems engineering, and I am motivated by the challenges and opportunities of the energy transition.

contributors.headline: Researcher | Lecturer | Power Systems | PhD in Electrical Engineering

projects.title: Flexible and Future Power Links for Smart Grids (FLINK)
projects.description: The FLINK flexible AC/DC-link concept is to repurpose an existing MV AC cable to transmit power in either AC or DC depending on the requirements/desires of the distribution network operator (DNO). The system is MV, and repurposes cables since the Dutch MV network is 100% underground. Of these cables, a majority are paper insulated, however, they are being phased out for cross-linked polyethylene (XLPE), and therefore any new links, or damaged sections of existing links, are installed with XLPE insulated cables. While oil-impregnated paper insulated cables can handle DC voltage and polarity reversals, XLPE insula-tion has challenges with DC voltages, space charges, and reversal of polarity when space charges are appar-ent. For this reason, another set of tests are proposed by the TU/e to test XLPE cable systems to determine how the link can be safely switched between AC and DC operations, if at all possible.
